title: MacBook pro overheating ?
body:
i'm currently owning a macbook pro early 2015 13-inch retina display.
When i'm playing league, my mbp gets really hot and reaches about 65°C.

Is this normal ? Does it damage my laptop ?

replies.body:
Ive played league for 4 years on a old macbook pro, and it got really really hot each time, and it just stopped being able to play league at high fps this year, nearing its 10th birthday (which is a long time to have a laptop) 

So if a 10 year old computer can run it for 4 years at the end of its life, I'm sure you have nothing to worry about.

I just got a brand spanking new one a month ago, and it still gets hot when playing league. So i think its normal. 
Be thankful your computer is nice metal that can take some heat, and not cheap crappy plastic like windows are.
Or. Just custom make a computer that isnt a piece of crap

if you're really that lazy just hire someone to build it for you, can be as cheap as $25, if you are willing to trust them, otherwise more like $75+

Still cheaper, but also stronger and more reliable.
But is it made of nice shiny metal with a clean corporate logo? Or is it a jumble of cheaply made plastic parts?

Obviously its a jumble of cheaply made plastic parts with a Nvidia sticker plastered on the side.

With 3 GeForce GTX 1080 stuffed in there, with a GT 630m 1 hooked up to the cheap 2007 model motherboard

> [{quoted}](name=Lord Sesshomaru,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=prp5087T,comment-id=00010000000000000000,timestamp=2016-06-02T20:28:38.182+0000)
>
> But is it made of nice shiny metal with a clean corporate logo? Or is it a jumble of cheaply made plastic parts?

Lol

install laptop fan.
its quite cheap at around $20 @

> owning a macbook

As a wise man once said: "well, there's your problem"

But in all seriousness, it's not that big an issue. As long as the computer is able to withstand the heat that is being generated (consult the owners manual or contact the manufacturer) it's not an issue. Generally laptops, especially lower-end laptops, will heat up for intensive programs, particularly things like MMO's/Online Multiplayer games such as League, SW:TOR, LotRO (IIRC) etc.
Well my 13 inch macbook 2012 can run it very well without ever heating up...
